content: quote: Originally posted by _cash_: Skytail, A Finnish friend of mine says "The only good Russians are dead Russians". Looks like you guys need to do a lot of PR if you want to be loved. I am afraid that Skytail and the other Russian posters and apologists seem constitutionally unable to see why their neighbours might dislike them. Furthermore they compound their error by believing that threats and bullying will draw those countries to them when all it in fact does is drive them further towards countries that they believe will contain Russia. content: Wow I didn't know that opposition political parties were illegal in Poland and the Baltic states. Poland just had an election IIRC and the government changed but how could that be if opposition was illegal? Unless you meant that opposition was illegal in Russia which is of course not the case - it's just very, very difficult to access the media or hold rallies or raise money if you aren't a Putinista. I don't think the term "Apartheid2 is totally accurate, not far off in some instances but it is possible for ethnic Russians to get along by learning to be a local in a way that a black African could not dye his skin. And the Kremlin emphatically did not help the situation by constantly giving the impression that it was going to "save" the ethnic Russians from their "oppressors" when it could do no such thing and then belatedly attempting to bully the Baltics into being nice to Russians long after the chance was past. Thus the Russians in the Baltics have spent the last fifteen years constantly looking back to Moscow rather than getting on and trying to integrate. Of course an apology for the sins of the USSR from Moscow might have helped as would a bit of humility from the Russian colonia planted by Moscow and then left to their own devices.

Of course an apology for the sins of the USSR from Moscow might have helped as would a bit of humility from the Russian colonia planted by Moscow and then left to their own devices. That’s funny! Baltic’s can flex their illusionary muscles (sadly, under the protection of the EU) for now, but it would be foolish for them to believe this artificial state of affairs will last forever! I’m not taking about an invasion by Russia per se, but sooner or latter France & Germany will get tired of their BS (along with their ever closer ties with Russia), and they will be left out to dry.....

content: quote: ... According to Estonian Law (am sure Latvian as well), all minorities who either emigrated to, or were born in Estonia after 1940 MUST take a test in order to become citizens; hence vote & participate in political process! In contrast, all former citizens of USSR can become citizens of RF by simply filling out a request! ... Impressive backpedaling, but still inaccurate. Those who emigrated (or were relocated) to Estonia in 1940-1992, and their descendants, have to apply for independent Estonia's citizenship. Application for a minor born to stateless parents after 1992, can be done separately. In essence, those who got their Estonian citizenship from the Soviet Union, lost it. Even though some 160,000 have gotten their Estonian citizenship, the interest for getting Estonian citizenship has been very low in the past few years, largely because they have the same rights in EU job markets and no visa requirements to Russia. Oh and minorities do have political parties. You know, exaggeration and misinformation doesn't really help the cause of stateless ethnic Russians in the Baltics.

They were Russians or Soviets so when the USSR fell those Russians remaining, even those born there, were in (eg) Estonia but not of Estonia. It is therefore not surprising that Estonia treated them as immigrants when they tried to join its citizenry. content: quote: You haven’t disapproved anything I’ve said! lol You said: "Russian minority (3rd of the population) is forbidden from forming political parties and/or participating in politics altogether in the Baltic’s"They're not forbidden to form political parties (see end of post for more). It's only the stateless persons who cannot participate in politics (8% in Estonia, 16% in Latvia, less than 1% in Lithuania - not even close to a 3rd of the population of the Baltics). You also said: "How can they “get along” when they have absolutely no rights under the Estonian, Lithuanian & Latvian law ..."Which is just so completely incorrect I'm not sure what to say. quote: If you were born in Estonia 1940-92, and lived there your whole life, you still have to apply and take a test in order to become a citizen! True, and that's an injustice in my opinion. Only some 3/5 of stateless persons have received citizenship so far, while the others have not (for various reasons). quote: So what was the point of your post again? To correct some hilariously exaggerated information. quote: Please educate me, tell me of one Russian minority party in Estonia! Sure. Let's see, in Estonia there are only two political parties that say their agenda is the Russian minority's "cause": Vene Erakond Eestis (Russian Party of Estonia) and Konstitutsioonierakond (Constitution Party, formerly Russian Unity Party, which is now merged with the Left Party to form the Estonian United Left Party, Eestimaa Ühendatud Vasakpartei). They're just not very popular, even among Russian Estonians who have gained citizenship. I can't find information on how many ethnic Russians are in the Riigikogu from other parties, I'd guess something like 10% based on surnames (but those can be misleading due to marriages and the descendants of the ethnic Russian population from Estonia's previous independence and before). And there are of course ethnic Russian Mayors, City Council and Municipal Council members.

content: quote: Originally posted by _cash_: Skytail, A Finnish friend of mine says "The only good Russians are dead Russians". Looks like you guys need to do a lot of PR if you want to be loved. I am afraid that Skytail and the other Russian posters and apologists seem constitutionally unable to see why their neighbours might dislike them. Furthermore they compound their error by believing that threats and bullying will draw those countries to them when all it in fact does is drive them further towards countries that they believe will contain Russia. It is a shame really, with the fall of communism and the collapse of the USSR the Russians had the opportunity to try and put history behind them and begin their relationships with the Soviet successors and ex-Warsaw Pact on a "clean slate" basis. Unfortunately all they seem to have done is sulked for a decade or so and then, when they've got some cash together, come out with the intention of treating their neighbours like vassals again.

content: Wow I didn't know that opposition political parties were illegal in Poland and the Baltic states. Poland just had an election IIRC and the government changed but how could that be if opposition was illegal? Unless you meant that opposition was illegal in Russia which is of course not the case - it's just very, very difficult to access the media or hold rallies or raise money if you aren't a Putinista. I don't think the term "Apartheid2 is totally accurate, not far off in some instances but it is possible for ethnic Russians to get along by learning to be a local in a way that a black African could not dye his skin. And the Kremlin emphatically did not help the situation by constantly giving the impression that it was going to "save" the ethnic Russians from their "oppressors" when it could do no such thing and then belatedly attempting to bully the Baltics into being nice to Russians long after the chance was past. Thus the Russians in the Baltics have spent the last fifteen years constantly looking back to Moscow rather than getting on and trying to integrate. Of course an apology for the sins of the USSR from Moscow might have helped as would a bit of humility from the Russian colonia planted by Moscow and then left to their own devices.

I’m not taking about an invasion by Russia per se, but sooner or latter France & Germany will get tired of their BS (along with their ever closer ties with Russia), and they will be left out to dry.....

content: quote: ... According to Estonian Law (am sure Latvian as well), all minorities who either emigrated to, or were born in Estonia after 1940 MUST take a test in order to become citizens; hence vote & participate in political process! In contrast, all former citizens of USSR can become citizens of RF by simply filling out a request! ... Impressive backpedaling, but still inaccurate. Those who emigrated (or were relocated) to Estonia in 1940-1992, and their descendants, have to apply for independent Estonia's citizenship. Application for a minor born to stateless parents after 1992, can be done separately. In essence, those who got their Estonian citizenship from the Soviet Union, lost it. Even though some 160,000 have gotten their Estonian citizenship, the interest for getting Estonian citizenship has been very low in the past few years, largely because they have the same rights in EU job markets and no visa requirements to Russia. Oh and minorities do have political parties. You know, exaggeration and misinformation doesn't really help the cause of stateless ethnic Russians in the Baltics.

None as far as I know but in my experience those who buy into the Russo-Serb "poor use, everybody picks on us, boo-hoo" bollocks is immune to any form of reasoned argument anyway. I am fairly sure that at least one of your claims is untrue because I distinctly remember seeing a BBC report on the tribulations of an ethnic Russian party in (IIRC) Latvia during their last election. They might not have had it easy but they did exist, amongst their major problems was that the government would only allow election materials to be put out in Latvian, which was a problem because most of the Russians (ans stupidly many of the candidates - it's a bit tricky to sit in a parliament that you can't understand) had failed to learn the local language. Of course a platform of reunification with Russia (most of the funding was suspected of coming from the Kremlin) didn't help... You are “fairly sure” and keep referencing “shows” on TV! And you accuse me of falling for myths! Does your knowledge of the Balkans (Serbs) extend as far as your “telly” as well? [COLOR:GREEN]"Fairly sure" is my way of saying that I'm pretty much certain but can't find a reference because BBC News only stores video reports for a few weeks. And for the record I consider BBC Newsnight to be a reputable current affairs programme (not an entertainment "show"), I have almost certainly read articles on the subject but that report happened to stick in my mind as a known source. BTW my knowledge of the Balkans does encompass television news and documentaries but it also includes, newspapers, books and the personal experience of myself and others. An RSM of my aquaintance summed up the Serb PSV myth thus, "They'd say they'd been victimised by a man if they'd got blood on their boots while kicking him to death." According to Estonian Law (am sure Latvian as well), all minorities who either emigrated to, or were born in Estonia after 1940 MUST take a test in order to become citizens; hence vote & participate in political process! In contrast, all former citizens of USSR can become citizens of RF by simply filling out a request! But the Russians in the Baltic states didn't think of themselves as Latvians or Estonians or whatever did they? They were Russians or Soviets so when the USSR fell those Russians remaining, even those born there, were in (eg) Estonia but not of Estonia. It is therefore not surprising that Estonia treated them as immigrants when they tried to join its citizenry. I wonder if this test is so onerous as to be too difficult for Russians to take or whether they just don't want to. If DC sent me a notice telling me all of the sudden I must take a test to prove I’m worthy of a citizenship, my answer would be short and to the point.....go **** yourself! [/color] The EU has on occasion come down fairly heavily of the Baltics for discrimination however given that much of the agitation is seen as coming from Moscow, and Putin not exactly being seen as a saint (eastern Europe developed a deep loathing for him when people started dying after he cut off the gas last winter) the larger mamber states are unwilling to be seen to do anything that would be seen as a victory by the Kremlin. For the third time; these issues arose as soon as the Baltic states got their independence....long before Putin and assertive Russia of today! And for the umpteenth time the Russians in the Baltic states were havering back towards the Kremlin as soon as those states got their independence. They'd had the whip hand for half a century don't forget and probably had every reason to feel threatened.

content: quote: You haven’t disapproved anything I’ve said! lol You said: "Russian minority (3rd of the population) is forbidden from forming political parties and/or participating in politics altogether in the Baltic’s"They're not forbidden to form political parties (see end of post for more). It's only the stateless persons who cannot participate in politics (8% in Estonia, 16% in Latvia, less than 1% in Lithuania - not even close to a 3rd of the population of the Baltics). You also said: "How can they “get along” when they have absolutely no rights under the Estonian, Lithuanian & Latvian law ..."Which is just so completely incorrect I'm not sure what to say. quote: If you were born in Estonia 1940-92, and lived there your whole life, you still have to apply and take a test in order to become a citizen! True, and that's an injustice in my opinion. Only some 3/5 of stateless persons have received citizenship so far, while the others have not (for various reasons). quote: So what was the point of your post again? To correct some hilariously exaggerated information. quote: Please educate me, tell me of one Russian minority party in Estonia! Sure. Let's see, in Estonia there are only two political parties that say their agenda is the Russian minority's "cause": Vene Erakond Eestis (Russian Party of Estonia) and Konstitutsioonierakond (Constitution Party, formerly Russian Unity Party, which is now merged with the Left Party to form the Estonian United Left Party, Eestimaa Ühendatud Vasakpartei). They're just not very popular, even among Russian Estonians who have gained citizenship. I can't find information on how many ethnic Russians are in the Riigikogu from other parties, I'd guess something like 10% based on surnames (but those can be misleading due to marriages and the descendants of the ethnic Russian population from Estonia's previous independence and before). And there are of course ethnic Russian Mayors, City Council and Municipal Council members.
